step_sequence: 1. Start with complete undirected graph|2. For each pair of variables (X,Y), search for conditioning sets S that make X,Y independent|3. If such S found, remove edge X-Y|4. Orient V-structures (X-Z-Y where X,Y not adjacent)|5. Orient remaining edges using logical rules
embedding_text: PC algorithm for causal discovery. Constraint-based method starting with complete graph and removing edges based on conditional independence tests. Assumes causal sufficiency and acyclicity. Outputs completed partially directed acyclic graph (CPDAG).

step_sequence: 1. Start with complete undirected graph|2. Perform adjacency search allowing for latent variables|3. Identify potential d-separation sets|4. Orient edges considering latent variables|5. Output PAG (Partial Ancestral Graph)
embedding_text: FCI (Fast Causal Inference) algorithm. Constraint-based discovery that allows for latent confounders and selection bias. Outputs Partial Ancestral Graph (PAG). More robust than PC but computationally intensive.

step_sequence: 1. Check stationarity of time series X and Y|2. Regress Y on lagged Y|3. Regress Y on lagged Y and led X|4. F-test for significance of X terms|5. Repeat for X on Y
embedding_text: Granger causality test. Statistical hypothesis test for determining if one time series is useful in forecasting another. Assumes linear dynamics and no instantaneous causation. Not true physical causality.

step_sequence: 1. Perform ICA (Independent Component Analysis) to decompose residuals|2. Permute rows to achieve strictly lower triangular matrix|3. Estimate connection strengths|4. Verify non-Gaussianity of error terms
embedding_text: LiNGAM (Linear Non-Gaussian Acyclic Model). Functional causal model based on ICA. Identifies direction of causality using non-Gaussianity of error terms. Assumes linear relationships and no unmeasured confounders.

step_sequence: 1. Start with empty graph|2. Forward phase: add edges that increase score (e.g., BIC)|3. Backward phase: remove edges that increase score|4. Return equivalence class of DAGs
embedding_text: GES (Greedy Equivalence Search). Score-based causal discovery algorithm. Iteratively adds and removes edges to maximize a scoring function like BIC. Returns the Markov equivalence class (CPDAG) of the true causal DAG.

step_sequence: 1. Identify treatment and control groups|2. Confirm parallel trends assumption pre-treatment|3. Measure outcome pre- and post-treatment|4. Calculate (Treatment_post - Treatment_pre) - (Control_post - Control_pre)
embedding_text: Difference-in-Differences (DiD). Quasi-experimental design for estimating causal effects. Compares changes in outcomes over time between a treatment group and a control group. Relies on parallel trends assumption.

step_sequence: 1. Identify valid instrument Z (associated with X, independent of U, affects Y only through X)|2. 1st stage: Regress X on Z|3. 2nd stage: Regress Y on predicted X|4. Check F-statistic for instrument strength
embedding_text: Instrumental Variables (IV) regression. Method for estimating causal effects when confounders are unmeasured. Requires a valid instrument variable satisfying relevance and exclusion restrictions.

step_sequence: 1. Identify cutoff threshold for treatment assignment|2. Verify continuity of potential outcomes at cutoff|3. Estimate effect at the cutoff using local regression|4. Checking for manipulation of forcing variable
embedding_text: Regression Discontinuity Design (RDD). Quasi-experimental design exploiting a cutoff rule for treatment assignment. Estimates local causal effect comparisons near the threshold. High internal validity.

step_sequence: 1. Select covariates influencing selection|2. Estimate propensity score P(Treatment|Covariates)|3. Match treated/control units on propensity score|4. Check balance of covariates after matching|5. Estimate treatment effect on matched sample
embedding_text: Propensity Score Matching (PSM). observational method to reduce selection bias by matching treated and control units with similar probabilities of receiving treatment. Mimics some characteristics of an RCT.

step_sequence: 1. Define donor pool of control units|2. Construct weighted combination of donors to match treated unit pre-treatment|3. Compare post-treatment trajectories|4. Placebo tests for inference
embedding_text: Synthetic Control Method. Constructs a data-driven counterfactual for a single treated unit using a weighted combination of control units. Useful for comparative case studies (e.g., policy impact on a region).
